Situation1: They are asked to take an active role in leading a significant family ceremony to preserve tradition.
Expectation2: Help out during difficult times or emergencies.
Situation2: You get a I04antic call I04om your I04iend whose car has broken down on the side of the highway late at night, and they need you to come get them immediately.
Story: Tonight, my family gathered for our annual ancestral ceremony, a tradition my parents hold dear. This year, they asked me to lead the ritual, a role of honor and responsibility. I could see the pride in my mother’s eyes as she handed me the incense, whispering about how important it was to keep our heritage alive. Just as I was about to begin, my phone buzzed urgently. It was Mia, my closest friend, her voice trembling as she told me her car had broken down on the highway, miles from home, and she was scared and alone. She begged me to come get her right away. My heart pounded as I looked at my family, waiting expectantly, and then at my phone, Mia’s messages piling up. I felt torn in two—my parents counting on me to honor our ancestors, Mia needing me more than ever. The weight of both worlds pressed down on me, and I stood frozen, unable to move, caught between the daughter I was raised to be and the friend I promised I’d always be.
